Question 1.Question: One of the major features of book keeping is that it
Question 1.Explanation: Book keeping ensures that appropriate and permanent records are kept for every financial transaction. The main feature or objective of book keeping is to maintain complete records of your business transactions by following the correct accounting rules and regulations in the country. Permanent financial records are very important for the future growth of your business.

Options.Value: Conservatism
Historical
Monetary
Cost

Question 2.Question: Which of the following accounting conventions suggests that accountants should use a method of valuation that understates rather than over-states results?
Question 2.Explanation: Conservatism conventions points that accountants should undertake the valuation of profit and make necessary provision for loss rather than overstating profit. This policy tends to understate rather than overstate net assets and net income, and therefore lead companies to "play safe".

Options.Value: Maintain the production section of the business
Know why transactions cause increases and decreases in assets
Advice on how to manage the business
Know how to record transactions in T account

Question 3.Question: A financial analyst needs accounting information to
Question 3.Explanation: A financial analyst is a professional, undertaking financial analysis for external or internal clients as a core feature of the job. Accounting information would allow the financial analyst to advice on how to run and manage the business.

Options.Value: Two credit entries at the same time
Two debit entries at the same time
Debit and credit entries in the same amount
Debit and credit entries in corresponding accounts

Question 4.Question: One basic assumption of the double entry theory is that it allows
Question 4.Explanation: Double entry theory states that every transaction is made up two part the debit (i.e. receiving part) and the corresponding credit side (giving part).The double-entry system of bookkeeping standardizes the accounting process and improves the accuracy of prepared financial statements, allowing for improved detection of errors.

Question 10.Question: An entry made in the bank column of the cash book to record movement of cash between the office and the bank is the
Question 10.Explanation: Contra entry is when the transaction involves only cash and bank. A contra entry is an entry which is recorded to reverse or offset an entry on the other side of an account. If a debit entry is recorded in an account, it will be recorded on the credit side and vice-versa.

Question 22.Question: In a period of inflation, which of the following methods normally gives a closing stock value very close to the market value?
Question 22.Explanation:
The FIFO inventory method refers to the timing at which inventory is purchased and subsequently used. Inventory that is purchased first is sold or used in production before inventory that is purchased at a later date. This method helps to

·Reduce Obsolete Inventory

·Reduce Impact of Inflation and Current Ending Inventory Value.

Question 39.Question: The entry in the partnership books of accounts for interest on drawings is to
Question 39.Explanation: Interest on drawings is credited to the partner's appropriation account and debited to the partner's capital account. Charging interest on drawings is a means of discouraging partners from withdrawing excessive amounts from the business. From this, it follows that interest on drawings is a debit entry in the partners' current accounts and a credit entry in the appropriation account.

Options.Value: Partners' capital account and credited to realization account
Partners' capital account and credited to asset account
Asset account and credited to realization account
Realization account and credited to capital account

Question 40.Question: In partnership dissolution, an asset taken over by a partner is debited to
Question 40.Explanation: Upon dissolution of partnership business all assets taken over by the partners are credited to the realization and debited to the partner's capital a/c.

Current asset
Fictitious asset
Liquid asset

Question 41.Explanation: Goodwill is an intangible asset and it is classified as fictitious asset in the statement of financial position. Goodwill represents assets that are not separately identifiable.

Question 44.Explanation: Ordinary shareholders receive dividend before and after the deferred shareholders and preference shareholders respectively. Usually, when a company is just getting started, they do not pay the dividend and the entire money earned will be reinvested into the business for further development.
